Question: What's the project size limit for the Small Distributed Generation (Small DG) category?
Answer: Small Distributed Generation refers to projects up to 25 kW in size. This category will comprise at least 20% of the Adjustable Block Program (ABP) capacity.
Start Text: 7.4.1. Small Distributed Generation

Question: What is the ABP capacity allocation breakdown during the delivery year 2023-2024 for the different program categories?
Answer: Small Distributed Generation: 20%; Large Distributed Generation: 20%; Traditional Community Solar: 30%; Public School Projects: 15%; Community-Driven Community Solar: 5%; Equity Eligible Contractor Projects: 10%

Answer: A REC is valued at $40.90/MWh for Utilities located in MISO (e.g., Ameren) and $33.31/MWh for Utilities in PJM (e.g., ComEd).

Question: What projects are eligble under the Public Schools categeory in the Adjustable Block Program in IL?
Answer: The Public Schools category includes projects that serve a public school in Illinois. Eligibility is restricted to projects that are installed "at" a public school, including projects on land adjacent to a public school or on school district-owned land.

Question: What is the rate of power that a 2MW ground mount system will receive from JCP&L?

Start Text: Energy Payment:

Question: Does JCP&L charge costs for interconnection or metering of a 10KW residential rooftop solar system?
Answer: Qualifying Facility (QF) customers shall pay all metering equipment and interconnection costs as required by JCP&L and/or by PJM.
Start Text: Cogeneration and Small Power Production Service

Question: Does Jersey Central Power & Light charge a fee to net-meter?
Answer: There is a $40.00 monthly service charge to JCP&L for Qualifying Facilities (QF) less than 1000 KW generating capacity, and negotiatiable for systems greater than 1000 KW.
Start Text: Cogeneration and Small Power Production Service

Question: What customers qualify under an NM1 net metering classification?
Answer: NM1 classification refers to a retail customer receiving bundled electric service from ComEd under Rate BES - Basic Electric Service (Rate BES), who consumes a portion of the gross output of its electric generating facilities and recieves the remaining portion of its power requirement in accordance with the provisions of the otherwise applicable tariff(s). Excess power from such electric generation facilities (e.g., solar PV) is provided to the Company (i.e., ComEd).
Start Text: These classifications are described in the following subsections of this Service Classifications section

Question: How does net metering compensation work for NM1 customers?
Answer: An NM1 retail customer is provided an energy credit, in kWhs, by ComEd for the net output provided to the Company by the retail customer during the monthly billing period, which may accrue over the current annual period. Accrued credits offset net kWhs, on a one to one (1:1) basis, supplied to the retail customer in subsequent months, during the current annual period.
Start Text: CREDITS AND COMPENSATION. A retail customer

Question: What Net Metering classification is a customer recieving generation from a competitive supplier under a fixed price contract?
Answer: A retail customer taking energy supply service from a RES under terms that do not include hourly pricing provisions falls under the NM3 classification. NM3 customers with on-site electric generation that exceeds their power requirements requirements will provide the net output of the system to the RES.
Start Text: NM3 Classification

Question: What is the compensation mechanism for exported solar power for a customer supplied by an RES at a fixed rate?
Answer: Since this customer would classify as an NM3 retail customer, they would receive a 1:1 volumetric delivery credit (in kWh) for excess power (i.e., net output) provided to the RES. Such volumetric credit may be rolled over to subsequent months within the annual period.
Start Text: A retail customer served hereunder with an NM1 or NM3

Question: How is a non-TOU DS-2 customer compensated for exported power from a third-party owned solar project in Ameren IL?
Answer: For service initiated before 2025, DS-1 and DS-2 customers shall receive a volumetric credit, for supply and delivery, from Ameren for each kWh of excess power provided by the customer during the billing period. Excess monthly volumetric credits may be banked for use during subsequent billing periods, prior to the end of the Annual Period, when unused credits will expire.
Start Text: If the amount of electricity produced by a Customer's Private Generation Facility

Question: How is a non-TOU DS-4 customer compensated for exported power from a third-party owned solar project in Ameren IL?
Answer: For service initiated before 2025, DS-3, DS-4 and DS-6 customers shall receive a credit from Ameren equal to the net amount of electricity provided by the Customer, multiplied by the electricity provider's (EP) tariffed or contract rate for electricity supply.
Start Text: Methodology B: 1. Customer receiving power and energy under non Time of Use Rates:

Question: Which type of customers is Net Metering available to?
Answer: Net metering is available to customers who own and operate a customer-generator facility that uses a NJ defined Class I renewable resource which is located on the customer's premises or contiguous property; is interconnected and operated in parallel with the ACE's transmission or distribution facilities; is intended primarily to offset all or part of the the customer's own electricity needs, and is not a Qualifying Facility (QF) served under ACE's Small Power Purchase Rate Schedule.
Start Text: Net Energy Metering

Question: How does the monthly rate change if a customer enrolls in a net metering program?
Answer: The monthly rates, rate components, and billing unit provisions are the same as those stated under the customer's existing applicable Rate Schedule. Only the per kilowatt-hour charge components will be affected.
Start Text: MONTHLY RATES, RATE COMPONENTS AND BILLING UNIT PROVISIONS

Question: How is a customer compensated for net metering?
Answer: If the customer consumes more energy than she delivers to ACE, she will be charged for the net amount consumed based on the rates and charges of her Rate Schedule. If the customer delivers more energy to ACE than she consumes, she will be charged the Customer Charge and any appropriate demand charges based on her applicable Rate Schedule. Then, ACE will credit the customer for that delivered energy.
Start Text: MONTHLY RATES, RATE COMPONENTS AND BILLING UNIT PROVISIONS
